Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Fundamental Techniques for Incentive-aware, Efficient, and Reliable Cloudlet Management and Services

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this work is to develop some fundamental techniques that can facilitate efficient management of cloudlet resources for high cloud service performance while minimizing the system cost. These techniques are to enable efficient, reliable and low cost mobile cloud services, which will in turn support high-performance wireless applications in an energy- and resource efficient manner. With this research, a cloud service provider can exploit sparse signal processing technique to remotely monitor one or multiple cloudlet clusters running in different location sites with high accuracy but low cost. To reduce the service initialization delay and operational cost, the system can cache application components, and a user can exploit the proposed rate dependent Bloom filter (RDBF) to quickly determine of some cloudlets have its required application components cached. Rather than being constrained by a limited number of options for virtual machine (VM) configurations, the system will be equipped with multi-dimensional pricing and resource negotiation capabilities for a user to flexibly negotiate multiple types of resources to maximize the benefits of both users and cloudlets while taking into account user application preference, performance requirements, and the system resource conditions.

Complementary to the research agenda, the project will carry out a broad range of education and outreach activities and facilitate technology transfer through the industrial partners and industry affiliate programs. The proposed research is part of a global effort in exploiting (mobile) cloud computing for advancing some critical fields for national economy and security, including health-care, transportation, smart-grid, homeland security, and education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this work is to develop some fundamental techniques that can facilitate efficient management of cloudlet resources for high cloud service performance while minimizing the system cost. We have completed 8 tasks in this project.

  1. Distributed Multi-dimensional Pricing for Efficient Application Offloading in Mobile Cloud Computing. We design MPTMG, a Multi-dimensional Pricing mechanism based on Two-sided Market Game, propose a distributed price-adjustment algorithm for efficient resource allocation and QoS-aware offloading scheduling, and prove the system can achieve the Pareto efficiency with the maximum benefit. This is the first paper that applies economic theories to managing application offloading in mobile cloud. Results demonstrate that MPTMG can significantly improve the system performance.
  2. Nesting the Data Center Network with Wireless Rings in 3-D Space: We propose a novel DCN architecture, Diamond, which nests the wired DCN with radios equipped on all servers. It exploits the low-cost deployment of scalable 3-D ring reflection spaces (RRSs) with interconnected wired herringbone to enable a large number of concurrent wireless transmissions through high-performance multi-reflection of radio signals over metal.  Diamond can support up to five times the server-to-server capacity.
  3. Traffic-Aware Virtual Machine Migration in Topology-Adaptive DCN: We propose a new paradigm for VM migration by dynamically constructing adaptive topologies based on the VM demands to lower the cost of both VM migration and communication. Extensive trace-based simulations show that our algorithms can achieve about four times the flow throughput among VMs with less than a quarter of the migration cost compared to state-of-art VM migration solutions. We also implement on OpenvSwitch testbed.
  4. Improving Synchronization Efficiency for Mobile Cloud Storage Services:  We identify, analyze, and address the synchronization (sync) inefficiency problem of modern mobile cloud storage services. We build the system on two commercial sync services. Our results show that QuickSync is able to reduce up to 73.1% sync time.
  5. Low Cost and High Accuracy Data Gathering in WSNs with Matrix Completion: We exploit cloudlet to facilitate efficient data gathering through matrix completion technique.  We propose an on-line data gathering scheme based on matrix completion theory to adaptively sample different locations according to environmental and weather conditions. Our scheme can collect the sensory data at required accuracy while largely reducing the cost for sensing, communication, and computation. 
  6. Improving the Service Profit of Geo-Distributed Clouds: To meet diverse user requests with random arrival time, we derive a new cloud operational model to help cloud providers make more service profit by properly selecting user requests to serve rather than satisfying them all. We propose two solutions to schedule offline and online request submissions respectively, and our solutions can achieve more than 1.6x the service profits of existing ones.
  7. Traffic-driven Topology Adaptation with Deep Learning: We present xWeaver, a traffic-driven deep learning solution to infer the high-performance network topology online. Our simulations show its significant performance gain in supporting higher network throughput and smaller flow completion time.
  8.  Achieving Efficient Routing in Reconfigurable DCNs: We derive a general interference model and propose a decomposition technique with proven performance guarantee, and solve the load balancing problem in reconfigurable DCNs with two algorithms to flexibly reconfigure network topology and enable hybrid-routing with paths consisting of both stable wired links and flexible wireless. Our solutions can outperform existing flow scheduling algorithms with the average throughput of large flows increased by up to 190%, the average completion time reduced by up to 72.6%, and the average completion time of small flows reduced by up to 64.5%.

The work has resulted in 7 journal papers and 6 conference papers. The search methods and results have been incorporated in the courses of wireless network and mobile computing.  We have trained four PhD students, one postdoc in this project, and two high school students.  This work has also drawn the attention from the Microsoft Azure group.
